options.desc: Input file format. The default is plain whitespace. Options are:

values.desc: A human-readable assembly format. A description can be found below.

options.desc: File to read input from (defaults to stdin)
File to write output to (defaults to stdout)
Execute the file using specific settings. This is the default using the precompiled setting. Options are as following:

values.desc: Use a simple reference interpreter that falls back onto a bignum based interpreter.
Use the reference interpreter with optimized data structures.
Use the bignum based fallback interpreter directly. This is the slowest option.

Compile the program into native code in advance, and then execute it using optimized datastructures. This is the fastest for short programs, or programs that have a long execution time. It falls back to the optimized interpreter and bignum interpreter when the native code encounters errors.},
Similar to precompiled, but this implementation compiles code it encounters while interpreting. This is faster for large programs that only actually execute a small part of their code.
Similar to precompiled, but compiles code in a separate thread while already interpreting. It is faster on large programs.

options.desc: Use the reference interpreter with no bignum fallback to count the amount of instructions executed.
Instead of executing, translate the file to/from assembly, and write the result to the specified output.
When translating, minify the resulting code by crushing label size.
Just compiles the program into assembly and dumps the result into a file. This is mainly for debugging.
Use wrapping arithmetic instead of switching to bignum-based interpretation when overflow occurs.

By default the interpreter generates an error when a missing key is requested from the heap. As the behaviour of the reference implementation of this is somewhat inconsistent, this option configures the interpreter to return 0 instead.
On overflow, generate an error instead of switching to a bignum interpreter.
By default, the compiler exits cleanly if the end of the program is reached, even when no exit command is present. This flag disables this behaviour.
